awd_titl_txt: Inuit/Arctic/Connections: Learning from the Top of the World (18th Inuit Studies Conference, October 2012)
awd_abstract_narration: This project supports the pre-preparation activities for the 18th Inuit Studies Conference, "Learning from the top of the World," to be hosted by the Smithsonian Arctic Studies Center in October 2012.  The Inuit Studies Conference is a premier international forum attended by over 500 Arctic scholars that includes Inuit representatives from Alaska, Canada, Greenland, and Ruissia, and this is the first time it will be hosted by the United States.   The five day conference will cover a wide range of topics including: indigenous knowledge in understanding global environmental change; international cooperation in Arctic research; the roles of museums and museum collections in preserving Inuit languages, heritage and cultures; Arctic governance and more.  The conference planning agenda includes robust public engagement through musical performances, literature and poetry readings, a film festival, evening lectures for the public, and exhibits in Inuit Art, photography, and science.   In addition, a website will be developed that will not only publicize and facilitate the conference but will ultimately provide educational materials and opportunities for students and teachers.

?????????Major goals of the 18th Inuit Studies Conference 2011 NSF Grant  were: to support the early work on the conference planning; development of the conference educational website; preparation of conference posters, program and abstract volume, and other educational materials; and curatorial planning for two exhibits associated with the conference.

Results:

Largest Inuit Studies Conference - From October 24-28, 2012, the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, DC hosted the 18th biennial Inuit Studies Conference (18 ISC) on the National Mall titled "Arctic/Inuit/Connections: Learning from the Top of the World."  Organized by the Smithsonian Institution's Arctic Studies Center, the ISC was e by many partners and sponsors. The 18th ISC was the largest ever ISC meeting as well as the first in the lower 48t. It included almost 600 Arctic scientists, anthropologists, linguists, archaeologists, historians, as well as educators, health and government specialists, and Inuit artists, filmmakers, and cultural activists from Canada, Alaska, Greenland, and Russia. It was one of the largest, if not the largest ever, gathering of Inuit and Arctic scientists, scholars, educators, community leaders, Inuit artists and youth in the United States.

First Online Inuit Studies Conference- the conference attracted an online audience of over 1000 people from 17 countries and 42 states. Amongst the highlights of the conference were the plenary talks by Lt. Governor Mead Treadwell of Alaska - on major social and political challenges in the North; Dr. Mark Serreze, Director of the National Snow and Ice Data Center - on Arctic climate change and its impacts; Nellie Cournoyea of the Inuvialuit Regional Corporation, former Canadian MP - on indigenous self-government; and Dr. Aron Crowell, Director of the Arctic Studies Center, Alaska Office - on the new role of the museums in supporting Arctic indigenous cultures.

Most comprehensive ICS conference program - the conference porgram featured 73 sessions comprised of 4-6 papers each, totaling over 300 presentations, roundtables, and discussion panels covering eight announced conference themes: Heritage, Museums, and the North; Globalization: An Arctic Story; Power, Governance and Politics in the North; the 'New' Arctic: Social, Cultural and Climate Change; Inuit Education and Health; Inuit Languages and Literature; Inuit Art, Film, and Media; Perceptions of the Past: Towards a More Inclusive Archaeology.

Multiple Inuit art demonstrations , exhibits, and film festivals open to the public - the 18 ISC featured a comprehensive Inuit Arts program including three Paulatuk Moonlight Drummers and Dancers performances from Arctic Canada; the first ever solo Inuit sculpture exhibition in the US by Inuit artist Abraham Anghik Ruben; Inuit print and tapestry exhibits; women sewing demonstrations; Smithsonian collections tours, and Inuit Film Festival.

Other achievements:

The conference planning process offered unique experience and training opportunities to two ASC young staffers, several interns, numerous volunteers and other collaborators, including Inuit youth from northern communities, prior and during the 18 ISC.
